parts.instructions: You are going to read an extract from a magazine article about working in the film industry. For questions 1-6, choose the answer (A, B, C or D) which you think fits best according to the text.

passage.title: Behind the Scenes
passage.content:
There was a small breeze when Marina came out for her lunch as she usually did, even when it was raining, instead of going up to the studio canteen. You could never get a table to yourself there, and whenever she sat with you always wanted to complain about the directors, the actors, the management or the canteen food. Everyone at Silver Screen Studios seemed to have a complaint of some kind.

Marina preferred not to have lunch at work because she wanted to avoid the canteen food. She wasn't particularly interested in the conversations. She found her colleagues were much too old for them. She also inherited the previous assistant's attitude towards the work, and this was because the management, partly due to Mr Rodriguez's weak administration and partly because it was thought to be sophisticated, was the only department in Silver Screen where you did not have to wear the studio uniform. This led to some confusion as to who was an assistant and who was a visitor.

Marina was wearing her blue suit today. She liked the blue suit. She had liked it for a very long time, she said, of a woman's advice that it was better to buy an expensive suit that would last than to keep buying cheap suits that looked very smart for a short while until they got dirty and lost their shape. The blue suit had been what the shop called a 'classic,' which meant that nobody would ever turn round in the street to look at it, but it would stand having its skirt taken up or let down according to the swings of fashion.

Marina was wearing her blue suit today. She liked the blue suit. She had worked very hard to earn enough money to afford it. When she first started in the film industry, she worked as an assistant to the food stylist. Her job was to prepare period food for historical dramas. She became fascinated by the research required to make the food look authentic for the time period being filmed.

'I never really paid much attention to history lessons at school and now this is one of the aspects of the work that I enjoy the most,' she explains. 'The film was set a hundred years ago and my job was to prepare the food for a dinner-party scene.'

Supermarkets stock most things all year round, but food is not always in the correct form for period dramas. 'Without the use of modern chemicals, vegetables probably looked a bit marked and oddly shaped,' Marina explains. 'And, if it is actually going to be eaten by the actors, hygiene must be considered.'

Few households of that era would have had an oven, so most meat would have been cooked over a fire. 'The work is obviously good fun, otherwise I wouldn't do it, but it's perhaps not as glamorous as people imagine,' says Marina. 'With a wedding cake or something like that, if it is cut before the director is satisfied with the shot, I have to go and make it look untouched again.'

parts.instructions: You are going to read a magazine article about food preparation for films. Six paragraphs have been removed from the article. Choose from the paragraphs A-G the one which fits each gap (7-12). There is one extra paragraph which you do not need to use.

passage.title: Creating Period Food for Films
passage.content:
Working as a food stylist for period dramas requires extensive research and creativity. Every detail must be historically accurate while still looking appealing on screen.

[7]

The biggest challenge comes when preparing food that actors will actually eat. Modern food safety regulations must be followed, even when recreating historical cooking methods.

[8]

Vegetables present another challenge. In historical periods, produce was seasonal and often imperfect. Today's perfectly shaped, year-round vegetables look too modern for period films.

[9]

Meat preparation requires special consideration. Most historical cooking involved open fires rather than modern ovens, creating different textures and appearances.

[10]

Desserts and elaborate dishes need to withstand multiple takes. A wedding cake might be 'cut' dozens of times before the director is satisfied with the scene.

[11]

The research process often involves consulting historical cookbooks, museum exhibits, and period paintings to ensure authenticity.

[12]

Despite the challenges, creating authentic period food for films remains one of the most rewarding aspects of working in the entertainment industry.

paragraphs.text: Food stylists must learn to artificially age vegetables to make them appear more natural for the time period being depicted.
This means carefully balancing historical accuracy with modern health and safety requirements for cast and crew.
Research begins months before filming starts, with stylists studying the eating habits and cooking methods of specific historical periods.
Special techniques are used to make multiple identical versions of elaborate dishes for filming purposes.
These cooking methods produced darker, more rustic-looking food than modern cooking techniques.
Art departments work closely with food stylists to ensure that dishes match the overall visual design of the film.
Many food stylists find this historical research to be the most intellectually stimulating part of their work.

parts.instructions: You are going to read a magazine article in which four people talk about their experiences working in media production. For questions 13-22, choose from the people (A-D). The people may be chosen more than once.

people.name: Carlos Martinez - Sound Engineer
people.text: I've worked on everything from documentaries to action films. The most challenging part of my job is recording clear dialogue in noisy environments. Sometimes we have to go back and re-record entire conversations in a studio because the original location was too loud. I always carry backup equipment because technical failures can shut down an entire production. The hours are long, but seeing your work on the big screen makes it all worthwhile.

people.name: Lisa Chen - Camera Operator
people.text: Every day brings new challenges in this industry. Weather conditions can completely change how we approach a shoot. Rain, snow, or extreme heat all affect our equipment and require different techniques. I've learned to adapt quickly and always have contingency plans. The physical demands of the job are significant - carrying heavy equipment and working in uncomfortable positions for hours. But the creativity and collaboration make it incredibly rewarding.

people.name: David Rodriguez - Set Designer
people.text: Attention to detail is everything in my line of work. A single misplaced object can ruin the authenticity of a historical scene. I spend weeks researching the periods we're recreating, studying everything from furniture styles to wall decorations. The budget constraints are always challenging - we need to create convincing environments without overspending. I love the problem-solving aspect and finding creative solutions to design challenges.

people.name: Sarah Kim - Script Supervisor
people.text: Continuity is my primary responsibility. I have to track every detail from scene to scene - what actors are wearing, how props are positioned, even which hand they use to hold objects. Memory alone isn't enough; I take hundreds of photos and detailed notes every day. The pressure is intense because mistakes can be very expensive to fix in post-production. Despite the stress, I enjoy being involved in every aspect of the filmmaking process.
